<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HOUSING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/supreme-court-throws-bidens-eviction-moratorium?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Eviction Moratorium Is No More
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/supreme-court-throws-bidens-eviction-moratorium?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A banner against renters eviction reading no job, no rent is displayed o..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NDE0L3VzLWhlYWx0aC12aXJ1cy1lY29ub215LXAuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Eric Baradat/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Supreme Court <a href="https://apnews.com/article/health-courts-pandemics-coronavirus-pandemic-daa34fb48a04dc9f3ddad94fb6b4cbb2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">put an end</a> to the moratorium that protected renters from being evicted during the pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a 6–3 decision last night, the court said that the CDC, which imposed the moratorium, didn’t actually have the legal authority to do that. In practice, that means hundreds of thousands of people in the US could potentially be evicted from their homes now that the protections have been tossed.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">There’s a long backstory</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So here are the SparkNotes. The original moratorium was introduced by the Trump administration with the goal of keeping renters in their homes as the bottom fell out of the economy. The eviction ban was extended a few times, most recently by the CDC through Oct. 3 for areas where Covid-19 was spreading considerably (more than 90% of US counties).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and <em>not</em> by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Even President Biden saw the </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/27/us/eviction-moratorium-ends.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writing on the wall</a></span><span>: “The bulk of the constitutional scholarship says that it’s not likely to pass constitutional muster,” he said earlier this month about the extension.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The ruling is a big victory for landlords, who’ve argued that they<em> </em>still need to pay their bills even while their income from tenants has dried up under the moratorium.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than Amazon's Fire Phone. Congress authorized $46.5 billion in rental assistance, but this week we learned that <a href="https://apnews.com/article/lifestyle-business-health-coronavirus-pandemic-68d5f61397c203fb9bd023f10671ee18?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">only 11%</a> of the total has been distributed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>with the federal moratorium scrapped, the Biden administration is asking local and state governments to enact measures of their own to protect renters from a wave of potential evictions. — <em>NF</em></p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FITNESS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/peloton-shares-slide-disappointing-quarter-price-cut-bike?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Peloton's Quarter Got Us Like
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/peloton-shares-slide-disappointing-quarter-price-cut-bike?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Image of a woman grimacing in a Peloton commercial" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NDE1L2ltYWdlX2Zyb21fYV9wZWxvdG9uX2NvbW1lcmNpYWwucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Screengrab from Peloton's infamous holiday commercial</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The fitness company said its <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/26/peloton-pton-q4-2021-loss.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">losses widened</a> during the latest quarter and warned that revenue for the current quarter won’t hit targets. It also reported a “material weakness” in its accounting processes that spooked investors—shares fell more than 6% after hours.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There is good news for anyone who wants to flex on their coworkers with a Peloton in their Zoom background, but balked at the price. The company is <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-slashes-price-on-exercise-bike-predicts-slowing-growth-11630013307?mod=hp_lead_pos4" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slashing</a> the cost of its OG Bike by about 20%, down to $1,495. “We know price remains a barrier,” the company wrote to investors.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Peloton’s fortunes soared in 2020 when quarantineers found that curling milk jugs just wasn’t scratching that fitness itch. This year has been a different story, as the company faces safety concerns over its Tread product and increased competition from the likes of Tonal, Mirror, and actual gyms. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...before yesterday’s tumble. — <em>NF</em></p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RACIAL JUSTICE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/26/corporate-americas-50-billion-pledge-fight-racial-inequality?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Are Companies Living Up to Their Racial Inequality Pledges?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="George Floyd memorial" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTc5L2dlb3JnZV9mbG95ZF9tZW1vcmlhbC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>KEREM YUCEL/AFP via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last June, US corporations pledged to give a historic sum of money to projects addressing racial inequality following George Floyd’s murder. The country's 50 biggest public companies, including Amazon, Apple, and JPMorgan, collectively committed at least <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/interactive/2021/george-floyd-corporate-america-racial-justice/?itid=sf_business" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$49.5 billion</a> to racial injustice initiatives, a Washington Post analysis shows.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">14 months later, where and how has the money been spent? According to the Post...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>$45.2 billion—more than 90% of the commitment—are loans and investments that went to support Black-owned banks, expand Black home ownership, and grow Black-owned businesses.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Most of the outright grants ($4.2 billion worth) went to groups focusing on economic equality, education, and health. Only $70 million went to organizations working on criminal justice reform specifically.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Remember, these are just pledges, so it is difficult to track whether the corporations have actually written the checks. So far, 37 companies have confirmed disbursing at least $1.7 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture</strong>: While financial muscle from Corporate America is welcome, some experts argue that policy, not philanthropy, is the most effective tactic to combat racial inequality.  <em>– SQ</em></p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There’s fast-paced work environments, and then there’s the <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N7442.3407870MORNINGBREW/B25957551.311314677;dc_trk_aid=497873726;dc_trk_cid=152108492;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">blazing-around-a-track-at-200-MPH</a> kind of work environments. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While most of us can’t say our jobs move at the same speed as the McLaren Formula 1 team, there is one thing we do share in common: <strong style="color:#000">Hybrid work is here to stay.</strong></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N7442.3407870MORNINGBREW/B25957551.311314677;dc_trk_aid=497873726;dc_trk_cid=152108492;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">McLaren counts on Webex</a> to help keep their foot on the gas in this new hybrid work reality, ensuring <strong style="color:#000">real-time communication and seamless collaboration</strong> on and off the track.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s all made possible with the Webex Suite—a unified experience for <strong style="color:#000">calling, meeting, messaging, events, and polling.</strong> In other words, you can shift gears about as fast as Lando right up there.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N7442.3407870MORNINGBREW/B25957551.311314677;dc_trk_aid=497873726;dc_trk_cid=152108492;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Learn more about how the Webex Suite is driving hybrid work</a>.</p>

GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/26/key-performance-indicators-august-27?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="NYC's Times Square" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NDEyL255Y19zX3RpbWVzX3NxdWFyZS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Alex Haney</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Throw your “New York City is dead” takes in the East River with all the other junk. NYC has <a href="https://www.zumper.com/blog/rental-price-data/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">passed</a> San Francisco as the most expensive rental market in the US, according to a report from Zumper. The median rent for a 1-bedroom in NYC is $2,810, compared to San Francisco’s $2,800. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Their security is awful.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">John Brins, a 21-year-old American who’s claimed responsibility for hacking T-Mobile, told the WSJ that breaching the company’s cyber defenses was <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/t-mobile-hacker-who-stole-data-on-50-million-customers-their-security-is-awful-11629985105?mod=hp_lead_pos10" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not particularly difficult</a>. Last week’s hack compromised the personal info of more than 50 million people. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>How water shortages are brewing wars. In practice, that means hundreds of thousands of people in the US could potentially be evicted from their homes now that the protections have been tossed.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThere’s a long backstory\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo here are the SparkNotes. The original moratorium was introduced by the Trump administration with the goal of keeping renters in their homes as the bottom fell out of the economy. The eviction ban was extended a few times, most recently by the CDC through Oct. 3 for areas where Covid-19 was spreading considerably (more than 90% of US counties).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eEven President Biden saw the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/27/us/eviction-moratorium-ends.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewriting on the wall\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e: “The bulk of the constitutional scholarship says that it’s not likely to pass constitutional muster,” he said earlier this month about the extension.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe ruling is a big victory for landlords, who’ve argued that they\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003estill need to pay their bills even while their income from tenants has dried up under the moratorium.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than Amazon's Fire Phone. Congress authorized $46.5 billion in rental assistance, but this week we learned that \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/lifestyle-business-health-coronavirus-pandemic-68d5f61397c203fb9bd023f10671ee18?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eonly 11%\u003c/a\u003e of the total has been distributed.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ewith the federal moratorium scrapped, the Biden administration is asking local and state governments to enact measures of their own to protect renters from a wave of potential evictions. — \u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe fitness company said its \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/26/peloton-pton-q4-2021-loss.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elosses widened\u003c/a\u003e during the latest quarter and warned that revenue for the current quarter won’t hit targets. It also reported a “material weakness” in its accounting processes that spooked investors—shares fell more than 6% after hours.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere is good news for anyone who wants to flex on their coworkers with a Peloton in their Zoom background, but balked at the price. The company is \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-slashes-price-on-exercise-bike-predicts-slowing-growth-11630013307?mod=hp_lead_pos4\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslashing\u003c/a\u003e the cost of its OG Bike by about 20%, down to $1,495. “We know price remains a barrier,” the company wrote to investors.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003ePeloton’s fortunes soared in 2020 when quarantineers found that curling milk jugs just wasn’t scratching that fitness itch. This year has been a different story, as the company faces safety concerns over its Tread product and increased competition from the likes of Tonal, Mirror, and actual gyms. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...before yesterday’s tumble. max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTc5L2dlb3JnZV9mbG95ZF9tZW1vcmlhbC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eKEREM YUCEL/AFP via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast June, US corporations pledged to give a historic sum of money to projects addressing racial inequality following George Floyd’s murder. The country's 50 biggest public companies, including Amazon, Apple, and JPMorgan, collectively committed at least \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/interactive/2021/george-floyd-corporate-america-racial-justice/?itid=sf_business\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$49.5 billion\u003c/a\u003e to racial injustice initiatives, a Washington Post analysis shows.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e14 months later, where and how has the money been spent? According to the Post...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e$45.2 billion—more than 90% of the commitment—are loans and investments that went to support Black-owned banks, expand Black home ownership, and grow Black-owned businesses.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMost of the outright grants ($4.2 billion worth) went to groups focusing on economic equality, education, and health. Only $70 million went to organizations working on criminal justice reform specifically.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRemember, these are just pledges, so it is difficult to track whether the corporations have actually written the checks. So far, 37 companies have confirmed disbursing at least $1.7 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture\u003c/strong\u003e: While financial muscle from Corporate America is welcome, some experts argue that policy, not philanthropy, is the most effective tactic to combat racial inequality.  \u003cem\u003e– SQ\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\"
